author: marvel89gg

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

title: Bug after converting java to bedrock
body:
### Chunker Version

1.4.5

### Platform / Operating System

windows 11

### Issue Description

After I converted the Java map to Bedrock, it turned out there was a bug. The bug was that when I opened the chat command in Bedrock, it didn't display (/) in the chat. Is this from Chunker or Minecraft?
author: FAIREHYPRYT

comments.body: If this is related to not being able to run commands, you will need to ensure the player your using has the Operator permission level in the world settings in Minecraft as Chunker doesn't currently set this.

title: Having issues with converting a specific world
body:
### Chunker Version

1.4.5-main-9b61a6d

### Input World Version

bedrock

### Output World Version

N/A

### Platform / Operating System

win32-x64-10.0.26100

### Issue Description

Error Displayed: `The folder you selected did not contain a level.dat, please ensure you're using a Minecraft world folder.`

Hello! I have a specific issue with a specific world that I can't convert.
Can someone please help I need to save this world.
Regards,
Nickki
author: Nickki-NL

comments.body: As per the error, please ensure you're selecting the right directory with the level.dat inside the folder. Otherwise Chunker is unable to read the world.

author: AFRATUL1

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

author: codibez

comments.body: The error you're getting is because Chunker can't open the world you've selected; this is usually because you have Minecraft open in the background. Please consider closing it and closing any other programs which have the world open.
The error occurs without any instance of Minecraft running, though the world comes from a realm that is online 24/7.

> The error occurs without any instance of Minecraft running, though the world comes from a realm that is online 24/7.

I would try copying the world folder to a different location and try again / potentially restart your computer.

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

title: Legacy console conversion
body:
### What feature would you like seen in Chunker?

I recently pulled my old worlds from my PS3 and I wanted to convert them to Bedrock for nostalgia. However, all the tools I have found where outdated and it wasn't possible to directly convert a world from legacy consoles to the Bedrock format. I had to use 2 seperate programs for that. First, MCC Toolchest (Which is quite old and could stop working any Windows update now) for converting from Console to Java. I then had to use another app, the Amulet Map Editor (Chunker didn't like something about the world, probably some thing on how MCC Toolchest handled the conversion) to convert the world from Java to Bedrock. While this did work it was cumbersome to do so for just one world, and it also did not copy any entities like wolves or iron golems. I think it would be a great option if it where possible to convert legacy console worlds into modern Java or Bedrock with just a few clicks. Thanks in advance for your time reading this.

Sincerely
Rob
author: TheRobLP

I could be wrong, but is there not a way in Bedrock itself to open old PS3 worlds? From a quick read it looks like you'd need to go between the editions, but I can't say I'm experienced with this.

Unfortunately, it's not really within the current scope of Chunker to add console support.

author: ehheehhehe

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

author: angelng17

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

comments.body:
We've not seen this one before, has the world been modified with any other tools? 

If you're able to provide the following so we can look further into the issue:

- The world if possible or a world that produces the same error, you can also email it to `chunker-public@hivemc.com`.

My map has been transferred from a lower version to a higher version, and I don't think I've used any mod during this process. I just updated it by upgrading my Minecraft server. I'm really sorry for causing this issue, as the map is just too old. It's okay if there is no way to fix it. Thank you for your reply. (I'm sorry for using a translation tool; my English is not very good.)
I have already sent the file using the email address [2185309497@qq.com](mailto:2185309497@qq.com).

I did have a quick look and unfortunately, it's not something we can really fix. You might be able to open the world in Bedrock and explore it and it might fix the file, but it's down to corruption of the file (maybe over time) and Chunker unfortunately can't repair it.

author: JespyIngerYT

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

title: conversion from Java to Bedrock missing Player Heads and Armorstand details
body:
### What feature would you like seen in Chunker?

conversion from Java to Bedrock missing Player Heads and Armor-stand details such as posing and NBT Data.

More Entities ported over to Bedrock. The converted Java Maps  when converted are missing so much decorative content.

Much appreciated to consider to make the porting more robust .
author: Tsoccerguy3

comments.body:
Those features aren't implemented due to parity issues:
- Armor stands - Bedrock doesn't support any of the poses which can be done on Java.
- Heads - There are no custom textures on Bedrock.

If those are added to Bedrock in the future, we will be sure to re-review adding it.

title: Transfer issue of worlds that were once part of legacy minecraft
body:
### Chunker Version

1.4.4-main-40ddcf6

### Input World Version

Bedrock 1.21.51

### Output World Version

Java 1.21.3

### Platform / Operating System

Windows 11

### Issue Description

I transfered my worlds from legacy minecraft to minecraft bedrock on my nintendo switch. After that I used realms to send my nintendo switch worlds to my PC so I have my worlds on bedrock for PC. Everything went well, I can log into my original legacy minecraft worlds on minecraft bedrock for PC. The problem is that now I cant seem to transfer those worlds to minecraft Java, the version that I play in now. I was successful in uploading my Nintendo switch Bedrock worlds (Not the legacy ones) onto Minecraft Java with chunker, but I was still unsuccessful on uploading the legacy ones.

Thank you for your help on this issue.
It wont let me upload the output log for this, but Im willing to send it if im asked. Thank you!
author: ejimenezconc

comments.body:
If you would like to provide the log we can look further, but usually it comes down to this:

The world contains chunks / data which because of the process of converting it multiple times hasn't been upgraded to a version Chunker understands. You can fix this yourself, it is a bit time consuming but going into your world and placing blocks in each chunk causes Bedrock to upgrade the chunks and then Chunker will be able to understand the chunks and you'll see a better conversion.

author: gabriel44bot

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

author: cuttlefishthefreaker

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

author: Drugsrcool

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

title: redstone_wire / twisting_vines do not connect properly
body:
### Chunker Version

chunker-cli-1.4.2

### Input World Version

Bedrock 1.21.40

### Output World Version

Java 1.20.2

### Platform / Operating System

Windows 10

### Issue Description

# Converting Bedrock 1.21.40 to Java 1.20.2

## Redstone Wire

I only tested a single disconnected piece of redstone wire. These results raise concern for all other redstone as this is the simplest case.
This oss version converted redstone wire to `east=none,north=none,power=0,south=none,west=none`
The web version converted redstone wire to `east=side,north=none,power=0,south=none,west=none`
I believe both are wrong and they should have created `east=side,north=side,power=0,south=side,west=side`


## Twisting Vines

I tested a stack of 4 twisting vines.
This oss version converted all 4 to `minecraft:twisting_vines_plant` but I believe it should have converted the top to something like `minecraft:twisting_vines[age=7]`
The web version converted all 4 to `minecraft:twisting_vines[age=25]` but I believe it should have converted the stems to `minecraft:twisting_vines_plant`


## Wrap
This test included every single block so other than the glaring omission of minecarts, armor stands, and even boats (because the chest boats have inventories), this is looking like a pretty good replacement for chunker. Unfortunately I have run out of willpower to run further tests before the chunker web shutdown, any other errors will have to be found one at a time.
author: Ma3-a

comments.body: Thanks for the detailed report, I can replicate the redstone_wire issue, so we'll hopefully get that fixed. Regarding the Twisting Vines, do you have a specific map that replicates the issue? I was unable to replicate it, and my vines are visually identical converting from Bedrock 1.21.50 -> Java 1.21.4 (with `Calculate Block Connections Using Neighbours` enabled).
Just as an update, the latest release (1.4.3) should improve the logic of connecting redstone_wire.
Closing as we haven't heard back from you, if this is still an issue, please provide further details regarding the twisting vines and we can look further :)

author: Alembola

comments.body: This world doesn't want to convert for whatever reason. I think it's because it was built off of a marketplace template. any ideas how I can fix this?

Marketplace maps cannot be converted, this is not a bug, they are encrypted to prevent piracy and therefor you cannot convert them sadly.
You may close the issue :D
If you have a specific marketplace map you want to convert send me the name and I may be able to get it converted for you :D

> If you have a specific marketplace map you want to convert send me the name and I may be able to get it converted for you :D

I used a free marketplace template that makes presents appear at spawn, I'm shocked that it's encrypted lmao.
I don't really care about the presents I just want the base I created on the world. If you're trying to convert a separate world with the same template, it won't do me any good.

Thanks for the help btw I really do appreciate it : )

title: i cant export my world
body:
### Chunker Version

1.4.2-main-daee346

### Input World Version

Java .1.8.8

### Output World Version

Bedrock .R19.30

### Platform / Operating System

win32-x64-10.0.19045

### Issue Description

Error Displayed: `Your system ran out of memory while converting, please try again, use a smaller world or try a different machine.`
author: Killmanh

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

	Don't know what do you mean with the second one. Gotta improve the bot talking

The second point is asking you to send a world if possible to `chunker-public@hivemc.com`.

The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

author: YZBWDLT

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, you may be able to use the pruning tool in the advanced options of chunker.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

author: David540928

comments.body:
The error you're seeing is because Chunker doesn't have enough memory to convert your world, this is usually because the world is quite big, or you don't have enough available memory (RAM). Chunker by default uses 75% of your available memory, so you might find that closing other applications before converting your world allows it to use the memory it needs.

You can also tell Chunker how much memory you want it to use, you need to run it from command-line in the form of `Chunker.exe -Xmx8G` to tell Chunker to use a maximum of 8 gigabytes of memory.

Alternatively, if your world is on Java edition you might find that using tools like MCASelector allow you to remove parts of your world that you haven't inhabited removing the requirement of needing more memory.

We can look further, but in most cases a large world does require more memory (especially with compression of the files), if you'd like us to, we would need:
- The world size
- How much memory your computer has
- A copy of the world

In your specific case, you may want to just use Minecraft Java to upgrade the world as it will do it as you load the chunks.

comments.body:
This might be related to you using Windows 8, we've internally only tested on Windows 10 and above. If the folder exists:

- Can you send a copy of your main.log from `%APPDATA%/chunker-electron/logs`, you'll want to put that path into Explorer / Run dialog (Windows Key + R)
I'm so sorry,but there is no folder `chunker-electron` under `%APPDATA%`.

I've taken a further look and it seems like unfortunately `electron` dropped windows 8 support earlier this year so it's likely related to that. It is still possible to use Chunker but you'd have to use the command line version documented in the README, or use a PC with Windows 10 / Linux.

While the electron app is technically 32-bit, it will run the backend in 64-bit mode so it will use more than 4gb of RAM if it's available / needs to. This is usually needed with much larger maps, the core limiting factor if it's not using all your RAM will likely be disk speed / CPU.

author: Kusfo75

comments.body:
As long as you're running without any memory arguments it should be trying to use all the memory, there is a chance windows is using the memory for other things.

You can explicitly boot Chunker with the `java -Xmx16G -jar chunker-cli.jar` parameter to limit/set the amount of memory it should use, there are also various other parameters like `-Xms8G` for initial memory usage.

If you want to reduce your memory usage (assuming you don't have another machine you could run this on), you can set up the pruning settings or use a GUI tool like MCASelector to remove unused chunks. Unfortunately memory usage varies world to world and Java compression can sometimes be really good leading to a lot of unpacking of data while Chunker is converting your world.
Closing this, if you need any more help let us know :)

Closing, let us know if you have more info / other issues and we'll be glad to reopen.

title: Provide a Dockerfile and host it inside the github registry
body:
### What feature would you like seen in Chunker?

It would be nice to have container images for the Chunker CLI and Web Application. These could be hosted in the github registry, ensuring that not everybody needs to build the images on their own.

Edit: As I just saw it now, that the web application has been marked as legacy and has been replaced by the Java Application, but it would still be great to have the ability to run the Chunker CLI inside containers for automated world conversion.
However the wider user base would not profit of that, as not many need a service to convert java edition worlds automatically to bedrock edition.
author: KCodeYT

comments.body:
Docker don't work like this. You can expose ports from the docker for external usage. Using Docker to exposing CLI is not possible. 
As you said first, if it was a web service theire will be no problem to do this but as the app is now all in java runnable app you cannot longer do this. 

Edit: I didnt see the app run under electron (as described in the README.md). If the purpose of this feature is to generate a docker image of the app it's not complicated. But for the cli i still don't see the utility to use docker for this, a script can be more appropriate

I don't see this as something currently within scope, if Chunker changes in the future we'll be sure to re-review this but for now it's going to be a lot easier as zelytra said to make a script if you're doing that kind of automation so you can tailor it to your needs.

title: Transfer player data for the same name
body:
### What feature would you like seen in Chunker?

I think player data can be transfered for players that use the same name in both versions. i.e. Someone with the name "Moobloom" in Java Edition will have the same player data (inventory, etc.) in Bedrock version of the world because their Xbox name is "Moobloom" as well.
author: Peawies

comments.body:
The new open-source Chunker does transfer player data for the local player. 

In regards to multiplayer worlds, it becomes complicated as we'd need to link up the XUID / UUID and match usernames which isn't currently planned due to the work needed.
Alright, thank you.
